title: More than 50,000 homes evacuated as wildfire torches Southern California
text:
Flames and smoke rise from a building in Geyserville (Picture: Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)

A raging fire ripping through Southern California has already driven more than 50,000 people from their homes.

It is still not yet known what caused the blaze, although the state’s biggest utility company admitted its electrical equipment could have ignited flames in the north.

The inferno erupted seven minutes after a Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) power line was damaged – leading to widespread power cuts to prevent further breakouts.

At least six homes have burnt down in Santa Clarita while 49 buildings were torched further north in Geyserville, where 2,000 people were ordered from their homes.

Firefighters have also struggled to protect homes surrounded by trees, as exceptionally high winds sent hot embers flying into them.

Geyserville town in Sonoma County, California, where residents were ordered from their homes (Picture: Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)

Alejandro Corrales watched her home burn in Canyon Country, taking with it her mother’s ashes, and possibly a pen full of pet sheep.

She told KCBS-TV: ‘I’m literally seeing sticks and fire of what used to be our home. Everything in the house is gone.

‘The panels on one of the pens where we have some rescued sheep were too hot for my daughter to open, and so she couldn’t let them out.

‘So I’m probably sure that we lost them, too.’

Some tried to protect their homes with garden hoses, others rushed to rescue animals.

Strong winds are fuelling the wildfires in America’s most populous state (Photo by Neal Waters/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)

Los Angeles firefighters use helicopters in a bid to put out the flames (Picture: Garrett Cheen / MEGA)

Firefighters at work in a factory near Santa Clarita, California, where reports say more than 5,000 acres have been burned, including houses and facilities (Picture: EPA)

Firefighting efforts were hindered after a specialist helicopter was grounded when its windshield was damaged after colliding with a bird.

The winds fanning the flames are expected to continue today with additional power cuts to more than 386,000 people also being considered.

Over the weekend gusts of up to 60 miles per hour are expected with the potential for even wider blackouts.

The 2018 Camp Fire which killed 85 people, making it the deadliest in California’s history, was started by old equipment owned by PG&E.

Firefighters battle a wind driven wildfire in the hills of Canyon Country north of Los Angeles, California, Picture: (Reuters)

People drive on a freeway as the fire burns in nearby Canyon Country (Picture: Getty Images)

Yesterday the company reported a ‘broken jumper’ wire was found on a transmission tower Wednesday night.

The power cuts shut off electricity supplied to people’s homes but not long-distance transmission lines.

PG&E CEO Bill Johnson said it was too soon to know if faulty equipment started the fire.

He said the tower had been inspected four times in the past two years and appeared in excellent condition.
